bibl.title: Fuṣūṣ al-ḥikam
فصوص الحكم
The Bezels of Wisdom, the Wisdom of the Prophets
bibl.incipit: al-ḥamdu lillāh munzil al-ḥikam ʿalā qulūb al-kilam
bibl.explicit: Closing Words of Text (exclusive of any rubric or colophon which might follow it).
bibl.author: Ibn al-ʿArabī
bibl.date: Terminus post quem and terminus ante quem

noteGrp.note: The most famous and widely read of all Ibn ʿArabī’s works, containing the epitome of his teachings on the meaning of the perfect human being (al-insān al-kāmil). It takes the form of 27 chapters on the prophets from Adam to Muhammad, each associated with a knowledge; for example; the wisdom on divinity in the word of Adam: the wisdom of light in the word of Joseph. Ibn ʿArabī’s intention in the Fuṣūṣ is to draw out the interior, saintly wisdom of each prophet rather than the religious law which they brought.

bibl.note: A much copied and commented on work, verified by at least seven historic mss. The best is Evkaf Muzesi 1933, which is SQ’s riwāya. written in his hand in 630H, with two samāʿ in IA’s hand. Other early mss: Kastamonu Hk 2024 (710H), Paris 1340 (726H), Corum Hk 3909 (728H), Konya Ak 308 (757H)

Cette rubrique, comme celle de RG. 135 (= Futûhât makkiyya) est l'une des plus importantes du Répertoire Général et sa mise à jour requiert la collaboration de tous les scholars travaillant sur Ibn Arabî. Je me borne pour l'instant à noter quelques addenda correspondant aux informations que j'ai sous la main. Critical edition by Mahmud Kiliç and Abdurrahim Alkiṣ (Istanbul 2016), fully vowelled based upon al-Kashānī’s commentary plus a facsmile of the oldest ms, Evkaf Muzesi 1933, written by Ṣadr al-dīn al-Qūnawi.
